bcl:lefttext.in:strong: The Health Authorities administer the Industrial Camps Regulation.

bcl:schedule.bcl:lefttext: If Board officers, in the course of their duties, find conditions in camps which may be of concern under the Industrial Camps Regulation, the matter will be referred to the attention of the appropriate officials.
Queries with regard to the administration of the Industrial Camps Regulation should be directed to the officials responsible for its administration.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: active falling area means the area within a 2 tree length radius of where a faller or mechanized falling equipment is located and equipped so as to be able to fall timber;
backspar means a tree rigged up at the back end of a work area to support a skyline;
bucker means a worker who cuts up trees on the ground;
bunk means a horizontal bolster that is fitted with a stake at each end;
butt rigging means a system of swivels, shackles, links and hooks which connect the haulback and mainlines and to which chokers are fastened;
cable logging means a yarding system employing winches, blocks and cables;
dangerous tree means a tree that is a hazard to a worker due to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: its location or lean,
its physical damage,
overhead conditions,
deterioration of its limbs, stem or root system, or
any combination of the conditions in paragraphs (a) to (d);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: faller means a worker who manually falls trees;

federal cargo securement standard has the same meaning as "Standard" in section 35.02 (1) [adoption of National Safety Code for Motor Carriers Standard 10 â€” Cargo Securement] of the Motor Vehicle Act Regulations;

forestry operation means a workplace where work is done in relation to silviculture or harvesting trees, including constructing the means of access and transporting the harvested trees to a facility where they are processed or from which they are exported;
haulback means the cable used to outhaul the rigging or grapple when yarding;
high lead means a cable logging system in which running line lead blocks are placed on a lift tree or on a mobile yarder to provide lift to the logs during yarding;
highway has the same meaning as in the Motor Vehicle Act;
holding wood means the hinge of wood left uncut between the back of the undercut and the backcut;
intermediate spar means a tree used to elevate a skyline between the yarder and the backspar in a multispan skyline system;
landing means the area to which logs are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: yarded or skidded for sorting, and
prepared for transportation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: lift tree means a tree rigged to support running lines;
log load means a load of one or more logs on a log transporter;
log stack means a log load that is a separate pile of logs of at least 2 layers lying lengthwise or crosswise on a log transporter;
log transporter means any of the following that is used on roads to transport logs, other than within a fully enclosed container:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a truck;
a trailer;
a truck and trailer assembly;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: mainline means the cable used to yard logs;
mobile equipment means mobile equipment as defined in sectionÂ 16.1;

mobile yarder means a logging machine mounted on wheels, tracks or skids, incorporating a vertical or inclined spar, tower or boom used in a skyline, slackline, modified slackline, high lead, or grapple cable logging system;

molly hogan means a single strand of wire rope rolled into a circle with 6 complete wraps that may be used as a temporary method of connecting the eye splices of 2 lines of the same size or in pin shackles to replace the cotter pin;
multiple-employer workplace has the same meaning as in section 13 of the Workers Compensation Act;
prime contractor has the same meaning as in section 13 of the Workers Compensation Act;
qualified arborist means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has knowledge, through training or a combination of education and training, of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: tree-climbing activities, and
tree-climbing systems,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has experience

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: engaging in tree-climbing activities, and
using tree-climbing systems, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has, as appropriate to the work being done, knowledge, through training or a combination of education and training, of and experience

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pruning, repairing or maintaining trees, or
taking down trees in pieces or taking down parts of trees;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: sapling means an immature tree that ordinarily would not be harvested;
skidding means moving logs by the use of mobile equipment that travels while the logs are being dragged;
skyline means a cable on a yarder that supplies lift for yarding lines, blocks, rigging, carriage and logs;
slackline means a skyline that can be tensioned at the operator's discretion;
spar means a tree or mast on which rigging is hung for a cable logging system;
strawline means a small diameter cable used in rigging up or moving larger cables or blocks;
tiedown means chain, wire rope, synthetic rope or webbing, together with a tensioning device, that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: placed over a log load on a log transporter, and
attached to one or more anchor points on the log transporter;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: trainee arborist means a person undergoing on-the-job training under the direct supervision of a qualified arborist;

transportation route, in relation to a log transporter, means a route taken by the log transporter from the place where it is first loaded with logs to the place where its load of logs is fully off-loaded;
tree-climbing activities means any of the following work activities:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: climbing a tree for the purpose of a work activity described in paragraph (b);
doing any of the following while in a tree:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pruning, repairing or maintaining a tree;
taking down a tree in pieces;
taking down parts of a tree;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: tree-climbing system means the equipment a person relies on for support and security while engaging in tree-climbing activities, including a harness, climbing lines and lanyards;
turn means one or more logs that are skidded or yarded to the landing at one time;
wrapper means chain, wire rope, synthetic rope or webbing, together with a tensioning device, that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wrapped securely around a log load on a log transporter, and
not attached to the log transporter;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: yarding means moving logs by the use of mobile or other equipment that does not travel while the logs are being moved.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prime contractor requirements for forestry operations
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the owner of a forestry operation enters into an agreement referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of "prime contractor" in section 13 of the Act designating a person to be the prime contractor for a workplace, the owner must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person designated

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is qualified to be the prime contractor in respect of that workplace, and

has the authority necessary to fulfill the responsibilities of prime contractor under the Act, including, without limitation, authority over any employer, worker or other person who may be carrying out the work of the owner at the workplace, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not more than one person holds the designation of prime contractor for that workplace at any given time.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a multiple-employer workplace in a forestry operation.

Before starting any activity that is likely to create a hazard for an independent operator or a worker of another employer, the person intending to carry out the activity must notify the prime contractor.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Planning and conducting a forestry operation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a forestry operation must ensure that all activities of the forestry operation are both planned and conducted in a manner consistent with this Regulation and with safe work practices acceptable to the Board.

Every person who has knowledge and control of any particular activity in a forestry operation must ensure that the activity is both planned and conducted in a manner consistent with this Regulation and with safe work practices acceptable to the Board.
The planning required under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include identification of any work activities or conditions at the workplace where there is a known or reasonably foreseeable risk to workers,
be completed before work commences on the relevant activity, and
be documented at the time of planning.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, after any planning referred to in subsection (3), there is a change in the workplace circumstances, including the work activities and the conditions of the workplace, and the change poses or creates a known or reasonably foreseeable risk to workers that was not previously identified, then

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plan must be amended to identify and address the risk and provide for the health and safety of the workers at the workplace, and
the amendment must be documented as soon as is practicable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Planning and conducting activities involving trees
other than a forestry operation or tree-climbing activities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that work activities at the workplace that involve pruning, repairing, maintaining, bucking or manually falling trees, taking down trees in pieces or taking down parts of trees are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: planned in accordance with this section, and
conducted in accordance with the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: work activities carried out in a forestry operation, or
tree-climbing activities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The planning required under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the hazards and risks associated with the work activities to be performed,
identify how the hazards and risks will be eliminated or minimized to the lowest level practicable,
be completed and communicated to each worker involved in the work activities before the work activities commence, and
be documented at the time of planning.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, after planning takes place under subsection (3), there is a change in the workplace circumstances, including the work activities and the conditions of the workplace, and the change poses or creates a known or reasonably foreseeable hazard or risk to workers that was not previously identified, the employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plan is amended to identify

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the hazard or risk, and
how the hazard or risk will be eliminated or minimized to the lowest level practicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amendment to the plan is communicated to each affected worker before the amendment is implemented, and
the amendment to the plan is documented as soon as practicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every worker in a forestry operation must receive the training necessary to safely perform the worker's duties.
The requirements of subsection (1) are deemed to have been met with regard to duties of a type performed before April 15, 1998 if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker performed the duties regularly for at least 2Â years prior to that date, and
the duties performed were documented by AprilÂ 15,Â 1999.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Records must be kept, in a form and manner acceptable to the Board, of the training provided in subsection (1).
On request of a worker, a copy of the records under subsection (3) that pertain to the worker must be provided to the worker.
Workers in a forestry operation who fight a forest fire must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: trained in their fire fighting duties in accordance with a standard acceptable to the Board, and
physically capable of performing their duties safely and effectively.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Training must be provided annually to every worker who is required to fight forest fires and records must be kept of the training provided to each worker.
Except under emergency conditions, a worker who is fighting a forest fire must wear

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: long pants and a long sleeved shirt made of cotton, wool, denim or flame resistant material, or
other protective clothing appropriate to the hazards to which the worker may be exposed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applies to a workplace in a forestry operation where the work is expected to last more than 5 working days, but
does not apply where the work is limited to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: timber cruising,
forestry road or cutblock layout, or
surveying.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Not more than 30 days and not fewer than 24 hours before the start of work at a workplace, the owner for whom the work is being done must ensure that a notice of project is provided to the nearest Board office.

If it is necessary to do immediate work in order to prevent injury to workers or damage to property, work on the project may commence immediately, and the owner for whom the work is being done must ensure that a notice of project is provided to the nearest Board office at the earliest possible time.
A notice of project under subsection (2) or (3) must be provided in a form and manner acceptable to the Board.
In this section, new work location means a work location in a forestry operation where the crew of workers has not previously worked.

Before a crew of workers starts work in a new work location, a crew safety meeting must be held to inform the workers of any known or reasonably foreseeable risks in that location and the actions to be taken to eliminate or minimize those risks.

If a worker did not attend the crew safety meeting under subsection (2) for a new work location, before starting work in that location, the worker must receive a safety orientation that covers any known or reasonably foreseeable risks in that location and the actions taken to eliminate or minimize those risks.
Records must be kept of the crew safety meetings and safety orientations provided under subsections (2) and (3).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 7.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Highly visible outer clothing that meets the requirements of Part 8 must be worn by a worker in a forestry operation if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker may be endangered by any moving equipment or line,
the worker's location must be routinely checked, or
the worker is involved in harvesting trees at night.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Safety headgear worn by a worker in a forestry operation must be a high visibility colour that contrasts with the background against which the worker is working.
In this section, climber means a worker in a forestry operation who climbs trees or wooden spars at the workplace.
Unless a climber uses other equipment acceptable to the Board, a climber must use

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a safety belt,
a climbing rope or strap, and
climbing spurs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a climber must disconnect the climbing rope or strap in order to move by an obstacle, the climber must use a second climbing rope or strap to ensure continuous protection while passing the obstacle.
Before a climber begins a climbing activity, a written climber rescue plan must be developed and communicated to all persons associated with the climbing activity.
If a climber rescue plan requires another climber,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a duplicate set of climbing equipment must be available for immediate use at the climbing work site, and
the other climber must be available to carry out any required rescue.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, with respect to a climber, there is a possibility of a climbing rope or strap being severed in the conditions present at a climbing work site, then

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the rope or strap must be made of material that cannot be severed, or
the climber must use a second climbing rope or strap.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Climbing equipment used by a climber must be maintained in good order.
A climber must inspect the climbing equipment before each use to ensure it is in good order.

bcl:section.bcl:text: When weather conditions create a hazard for a worker in a forestry operation, additional precautions must be taken as necessary for the safe conduct of the work.
A hammer or axe must not be used to cut wire rope, unless designed for that purpose.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. D, s. 28.]
A spike, drift bolt, nail, or any other metal must not be left in any recoverable log.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If it is known or reasonably foreseeable that work will expose a worker to a dangerous tree,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tree must be felled, or
a risk assessment of the tree must be undertaken by a person who has completed a training program acceptable to the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a risk assessment under subsection (1) determines that a tree poses a risk to a worker, the recommendations made in the risk assessment for eliminating or minimizing the risk must be implemented before the work referred to in that subsection starts.

Despite subsections (1) and (2), if work in a forestry operation is to be carried out in an area that has more than 500 dangerous trees per hectare, the Board may approve a request to work without felling or assessing all the dangerous trees if, before the work starts,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who has completed a training program acceptable to the Board conducts a risk assessment of a representative sample of the dangerous trees, and
any recommendations made in the risk assessment for eliminating or minimizing the risks are implemented.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. A, s. 57.]
Sections 26.12.0.2 to 26.12.0.6 apply in relation to tree-climbing activities at a workplace other than a forestry operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that only a qualified arborist or trainee arborist engages in tree-climbing activities at the workplace.
Before a qualified arborist or trainee arborist engages in tree-climbing activities at the workplace, the employer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that a qualified arborist determines that each tree that is intended to be climbed is able to withstand the loads intended to be imposed on it by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the tree-climbing activities, and
the work activities to be performed on the ground in the area around the tree, or around other trees, that relate to the tree-climbing activities,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a tree-climbing plan is prepared by a qualified arborist or trainee arborist in accordance with section 26.12.0.3Â (1) for the trees that a qualified arborist or trainee arborist intends to climb and determines are able to withstand the loads described in paragraphÂ (a) of this subsection, and

the tree-climbing plan, as documented under section 26.12.0.3 (1) (c), is communicated to each worker involved in the tree-climbing activities or the work activities described in paragraphÂ (a)Â (ii) of this subsection, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the tree-climbing plan referred to in paragraph (b) is prepared by a trainee arborist, ensure that the plan is approved by a qualified arborist.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In preparing a tree-climbing plan referred to in section 26.12.0.2Â (2)Â (b), a qualified arborist or trainee arborist must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for each tree that is intended to be climbed or that may be impacted by the tree-climbing activities,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: visually assess and identify the hazards and risks associated with

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the structure of the tree, including the shape, lean, root collar, roots, stems, trunk and branches,
the recurring patterns of tree failure associated with the species of the tree, such as rot, root damage or stem damage,
the work activities to be performed on the ground in the area around the tree, or around other trees, that relate to the tree-climbing activities, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: identify how the hazards and risks identified under subparagraph (i) will be eliminated or minimized to the lowest level practicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for each tree that is intended to be climbed, identify

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the tree-climbing system to be used in climbing the tree,
the type and location of the initial anchor point to be used in the tree,
the name and duties of each worker involved in the tree-climbing activities or the work activities described in paragraphÂ (a)Â (i)Â (D),
the appropriate personal protective equipment to be used by each worker involved in the tree-climbing activities or the work activities described in paragraphÂ (a)Â (i)Â (D),

an effective means of communication to be used between the qualified arborist or trainee arborist, as applicable, and the workers involved in any work activities described in paragraphÂ (a)Â (i)Â (D), and

the emergency response, evacuation and rescue procedures to be used in the event of an equipment malfunction, a fall, an injury or the incapacity of a qualified arborist or trainee arborist to self-rescue when engaging in the tree-climbing activities, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: document the information described in paragraphs (a) (ii) and (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, after preparing a tree-climbing plan in accordance with subsection (1), a qualified arborist or trainee arborist becomes aware of a known or reasonably foreseeable hazard or risk described in subsectionÂ (1)Â (a)Â (i) that was not previously identified, the qualified arborist or trainee arborist must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend the tree-climbing plan so it identifies how the hazard or risk will be eliminated or minimized to the lowest level practicable,
communicate the amendment to each affected worker before the amendment is implemented, and
document the amendment as soon as practicable.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A qualified arborist or trainee arborist engaging in tree-climbing activities must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess and determine that each anchor point or other point of securement is suitable for the loads to be imposed on it before using it,
ensure each climbing line of the tree-climbing system

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: uses at least one anchor point or other point of securement in the tree,
uses independent anchor points or other points of securement, if practicable, and

is positioned at each anchor point or other point of securement in such a way that the climbing line will not move away from, though the climbing line may slide through, the anchor point or other point of securement,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: position the tree-climbing system in a manner that minimizes the risk of the qualified arborist or trainee arborist falling and colliding with an object while swinging on a climbing line in a pendulum-like motion,
tie a stopper knot at the end of each climbing line of the tree-climbing system,
before accessing the tree, be secured to the tree by the tree-climbing system and remain secured until the work is completed and the qualified arborist or trainee arborist has returned to the ground,
operate a cutting tool only when tied into the tree with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a climbing line or lanyard, and
a second means of securement, such as another climbing line or lanyard, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: engage in the tree-climbing activities in accordance with the parts of the tree-climbing plan described in section 26.12.0.3Â (1)Â (a)Â (ii) and (b)Â (i), (ii) andÂ (v).

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that a qualified arborist or trainee arborist engaging in tree-climbing activities can be promptly rescued in accordance with the procedures described in section 26.12.0.3Â (1)Â (b)Â (vi) that relate to the tree that is climbed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that a tree-climbing system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consists of pieces of equipment that are suitable for their use in the tree-climbing system and compatible with other pieces of equipment in the tree-climbing system,
is sufficient to support any loads likely to be imposed on it,
is kept free from substances and conditions that could contribute to the deterioration of the equipment, and
is not used for any purpose other than climbing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that a tree-climbing system is inspected by a qualified arborist before the tree-climbing system is first used on each work shift.
The employer must ensure that each piece of equipment in a tree-climbing system is removed from service

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as specified by the manufacturer of the equipment, or
if the equipment is defective.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that all of a tree-climbing system is immediately removed from service if one or more pieces of equipment in the tree-climbing system arrest a fall.

The employer must ensure that, if a piece of equipment in a tree-climbing system is removed from service under subsectionÂ (3) or all of a tree-climbing system is removed from service under subsection (4), the piece of equipment or the tree-climbing system, as applicable, is not returned to service until it has been inspected and certified safe for use by the manufacturer or its authorized agent or by a professional engineer.
Any equipment designed for a specific function in a forestry operation or adapted for use in a forestry operation must be capable of performing safely the functions for which it is being used.
The requirements of subsection (1) are met if the equipment is used

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions,
as specified by a professional engineer, or
in a manner acceptable to the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Mobile equipment used for lifting or hoisting logs is exempt from the requirements of section 16.31.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In a forestry operation, any equipment that is controlled by a remote control device must be equipped with a "fail safe" or "stop" mechanism that becomes operational if the remote control device fails.
Foot controls, floors, steps and similar surfaces where workers in a forestry operation walk or stand must be constructed of, or covered with, a non-slip material suitable for the footwear worn.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Protective guards must be provided and used on a self-loading log transporter or similar equipment unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is not practicable to do so, and
the absence of guards does not pose a hazard to the equipment operator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The heel bar on the operator's side of the loader boom of a self-loading log transporter must be equipped with a deflector shelf and must not be used for heeling logs.
If pushing or pulling the boom too far on logging equipment could cause the backstop to crush the equipment operator's cab, boom stops must be installed on the equipment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Log handling equipment must not be moved with a load lifted higher than is necessary to provide unobstructed vision for the equipment operator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A mobile yarder must have a permanently attached, legible and easily visible sign provided by the equipment manufacturer or a professional engineer that includes the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the manufacturer and the date of manufacture of the yarder, unless this information cannot be determined;
the model and serial number of the yarder, unless this information cannot be determined;
if the yarder is designed for skyline, slackline or modified slackline systems, the maximum and minimum size of skyline, mainline and haulback that must be used;
the maximum diameter of the mainline of the yarder;
if required for the yarder, the minimum size, number and placement of guylines;
if required for the yarder, the placement and number of outriggers;
the permissible yarding angles of the yarder;
the auxiliary equipment that may be safely attached to the yarder.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) is satisfied if the information is available at the workplace where the mobile yarder is located.
A mobile yarder must be rigged and used in accordance with the information provided under subsection (1) (c) to (h).
A mobile yarder must not be moved with the spar or tower in the vertical operating position unless the stability of the equipment can be maintained.
Multiple throttle controls on a mobile yarder must be arranged to prevent the simultaneous operation of 2 or more controls.
A mobile yarder and its attached equipment must be inspected frequently and at least as often as specified in the equipment manufacturer's instructions.
Manufacturer's manuals for a mobile yarder must be available, at the workplace where the yarder is located, to the following persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the yarder operator;
any person maintaining the yarder.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, saw chain shot means one or more parts of a saw chain travelling at a high speed as a result of the saw chain breaking.
This section applies to mobile equipment that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: used in mechanical falling activities or log processing,
equipped with a saw that cuts using a saw chain, and
manufactured on or after May 1, 2019.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Mobile equipment referred to in subsection (2) must meet one of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mobile equipment must have protective guards or other devices that prevent the mobile equipment's cab windows from being directly struck by saw chain shot from the mobile equipment's saw chain;
each cab window that could be directly struck by saw chain shot from the mobile equipment's saw chain must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: be made of one or more sheets of polycarbonate that have a total thickness of at least 32 mm (1.25 in), or

meet or exceed the requirements of the level 1 outdoor use ballistics tests of ANSI/UL 752, Standard for Bullet-Resisting Equipment, 11th edition (with revisions up to and including December 11, 2015).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (3), saw chain shot that ricochets off an object and then strikes a cab window is not considered to have directly struck the cab window.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 13.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A hazard area created by the operation of logging equipment must be identified.
Every hazard area identified under subsection (1) must be communicated to all workers in close proximity to the operating logging equipment and to the hazard area.

A worker must not enter into or proceed on foot through a hazard area referred to in subsection (1) unless the equipment operator first gives permission to the worker in a clear and unmistakable manner.
A safe work area must be designated for workers on foot in close proximity to any operating logging equipment.
The boundaries of a safe work area designated under subsection (1) must be communicated to all workers within and in close proximity to the safe work area.
No equipment may enter into or proceed through a safe work area unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment operator first obtains permission in a clear and unmistakable manner from all of the workers in that safe work area or from the supervisor of those workers, and
those workers take a safe position.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If vehicles on a road in a forestry operation are required to drive through a hazard area identified in section 26.14.1 or through a safe work area designated in section 26.14.2, effective traffic control appropriate to the hazard must be implemented.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 15.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. B, s. 58 (a).]
If the manufacturer's maximum slope operating stability limit for logging equipment is known, the equipment must be operated within that limit.
If the manufacturer's maximum slope operating stability limit for logging equipment is not known, the equipment must be operated within the following limits:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a rubber tired skidder must not be operated on a slope which exceeds 35%;
a crawler tractor, feller buncher, excavator and other similar equipment must not be operated on a slope which exceeds 40%;
any other forestry equipment specifically designed for use on a steep slope must not be operated on a slope which exceeds 50%.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsections (2) and (3) but subject to subsection (5), logging equipment may be operated beyond the maximum slope operating stability limits specified in those subsections if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a qualified person conducts a risk assessment of that operation, and
written safe work practices acceptable to the Board are developed and implemented to ensure the equipment's stability during operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite anything in this section, logging equipment must not be operated in a particular location or manner if its stability cannot be assured during that operation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 17.]

Mobile equipment used in forest operations and similar activities must have braking systems that meet the performance requirements of one of the following standards, provided that the standard applies to that type of mobile equipment as indicated in the scope of the standard:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ISO Standard 11169:1993 Machinery for forestry â€” Wheeled special machines â€” Vocabulary, performance test methods and criteria for brake systems, published May 15, 1993;
ISO Standard 11512:1995 Machinery for forestry â€” Tracked special machines â€” Performance criteria for brake systems, published March 1, 1995.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In a forestry operation where there may be a risk of a landslide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the risk must be assessed in accordance with a standard acceptable to the Board,
if a risk is found to be present, written safe work procedures must be developed meeting the requirements of the standard, and
workers must be educated in the safe work procedures.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 17.]
Sections 26.21 to 26.29 apply only to manual falling and bucking activities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not fall trees or be permitted to fall trees, or conduct or be permitted to conduct bucking activities associated with falling trees, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker is qualified to do so to a standard acceptable to the Board, and
the work being performed is within the documented and demonstrated capabilities of that worker.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) (a) does not apply to a worker who is in a falling or bucking training program that is acceptable to the Board.

A worker may not work as a faller in a forestry operation unless the worker receives training for falling that is acceptable to the Board and is certified in writing as a competent faller under this section.
Without limiting subsection (1), faller training must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: taking basic training in falling trees by working one-on-one with a qualified faller or trainer for a period of not less than 30 days;
in the presence of a qualified supervisor or trainer, taking a written or oral examination on falling;

after completion of basic training under paragraph (a) and passing the examination under paragraph (b), working as a trainee faller under the close supervision of a qualified faller or trainer for a minimum period specified in subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The required minimum supervision period in subsection (2) (c) is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 180 days, or
a shorter period as determined by a qualified supervisor or trainer, if the supervisor or trainer is satisfied that the worker is competent to perform the tasks of a faller.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person supervising a trainee faller under subsection (2) (c) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: evaluate the trainee's work on a weekly basis,
keep records of all evaluations done in respect of the trainee, and

if, at the end of the training period, the trainee's falling activity meets a standard acceptable to the Board, verify in writing that the trainee has demonstrated the competence necessary for certification under subsection (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If all of the requirements of subsections (1), (2) and (4) are satisfied in respect of a worker who is a trainee faller, a person acceptable to the Board may certify in writing that the worker is a competent faller.

A record of the training that is taken under this section must be maintained and kept in a form and manner acceptable to the Board and a copy of that record must be made available to an officer or the trainee to whom the record pertains.
Subsection (2) does not apply to a worker who satisfies all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker has performed falling duties regularly for at least 2 years before the evaluation under paragraph (b) of this subsection takes place;
the worker's falling activity is evaluated by a qualified supervisor or trainer and it meets a standard acceptable to the Board;
in the presence of a qualified supervisor or trainer, the worker passes a written or oral examination on falling;
the worker is certified in writing as a competent faller by a person acceptable to the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (7) (b), the qualified supervisor or trainer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep a record of the evaluation, and
verify in writing that the worker has demonstrated the competence necessary for certification under subsection (7) (d).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified supervisor must be designated for all falling and associated bucking activities in a forestry operation.
The supervisor designated under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that the falling and bucking activities are planned and conducted in accordance with this Regulation,
inspect the workplace of each faller at time intervals appropriate to the risks, and
keep a record of every inspection conducted under paragraph (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The supervisor designated under subsection (1) must not undertake or be assigned activities which interfere with performance of the supervisor's duties under subsection (2).

In this section and in section 26.24, brushing means the striking of a standing tree by a tree being felled if the strike is a direct blow or a glancing blow of sufficient force to cause one or more branches to break at or near the stem of the standing tree.

Fallers and buckers associated with falling activities must be provided with and follow written safe work practices acceptable to the Board for the type of work activity they perform, including procedures for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing minimum and maximum distances between fallers and other workers;
planning and constructing escape routes;
controlling the fall of trees;
minimizing unnecessary brushing;
dealing with dangerous trees;
bucking trees and logs;
using mechanical assistance to fall trees;
summoning and rendering assistance to manage a falling difficulty or to deal with an emergency;
conducting special or innovative harvesting techniques;
ensuring the well-being of each faller and bucker at least every half hour and at the end of the work shift.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 26.29 (3), before a tree is felled, all workers must be clear of the area within a 2 tree-length radius of the tree.
Before falling or bucking starts, all obstructions to the activity must be cleared and a safe escape route to a predetermined safe position must be prepared.
A tree must not be felled if it could strike any stationary or running line of any operational equipment.
If it is necessary to pack or shovel snow to reduce stump height, the depth of the depression at the base of the tree must not exceed 45 cm (18 in.).
The falling of a tree must be conducted in accordance with the following procedures:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a sufficient undercut must be used;
the undercut must be complete and cleaned out;
sufficient holding wood must be maintained;
the backcut must be higher than the undercut to provide a step on the stump;
wedging tools must be immediately available and, unless the tree has a pronounced favourable lean, wedges must be set.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When a tree is being felled, the tree must not brush standing trees if that can be avoided.
A tree must not be used to cause another partially cut tree to fall in succession unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is necessary to do so to overcome a specific falling difficulty, and
the succession falling is done in accordance with subsection (6.1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following apply for the purposes of subsection (6):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only one tree may be used to cause another partially cut tree to fall in succession;
only those trees necessary to deal with the falling difficulty referred to in subsection (6) are partially cut;
a wedge is driven into the backcut of each partially cut tree.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When a tree starts to fall, the faller and any other worker present must move quickly to a predetermined safe position, at least 3Â m (10Â ft.) away from the base of the tree where possible, and take cover if available.
All workers must be clear of the hazard area before a tree or log is bucked.
Falling or bucking must not be started if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tree or log is in a condition that, if felled or bucked in that condition, the tree or log would pose a reasonably foreseeable risk to a worker, or
it appears that the tree cannot be completely felled or the bucking cut cannot be completed, as the case may be.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If for any reason a partially cut tree cannot be completely felled and must be bypassed or left unattended, then the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tree must be clearly marked;
work, other than that necessary to complete the falling of the tree, must stop in the hazard area until the tree is felled;
any worker who could enter the hazard area must be alerted to the hazard;
the supervisor for that falling activity must be notified.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The supervisor referred to in subsection (2) (d) must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all workers at risk are notified, and
the tree is safely felled before other work is undertaken in the hazard area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bucking cut cannot be completed and the partially bucked log must be bypassed or left unattended, then the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if possible, a distinct cross must immediately be cut or marked on the top of each end of the log;
the supervisor for the bucking activity must be notified at the end of the work day;
the supervisor for the bucking activity must notify all workers at risk.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsections (2) to (4) do not apply if the incomplete falling or bucking is part of a planned process in which safe work practices acceptable to the Board are implemented.
Where practicable, dangerous trees must be felled

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: progressively with the falling of other timber but before falling adjacent live trees, and
into open areas.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When falling a dangerous tree,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dangerous bark must be removed, where practicable,
stump height must, in the judgment of the faller, allow maximum visibility and freedom of action,
the tree must be felled in the direction of lean whenever possible, and the undercut must be as deep as necessary to minimize the use of wedges and resulting vibration,
pushing with a green tree must only be undertaken to overcome a falling difficulty, and
wedging over must be used only if there is no alternative, and after a careful assessment of the ability of the dangerous tree to withstand wedging.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If conventional methods cannot be safely employed to fall a dangerous tree, blasting or other acceptable methods must be used.

Falling, bucking or limbing activities must not be undertaken in an area made hazardous by a dangerous tree, or a dangerous tree which has been brushed by a felled tree, until the dangerous tree has been felled.
Fallers and buckers must not work in a location where they or other workers could be endangered by that work.
If an elevation or steep slope poses a risk to a faller, the faller must be provided with and use an appropriate fall protection system.
Any fall protection provided under subsection (2) must not impede the ability of the faller to move to a predetermined safe position as required in section 26.24 (7).
A faller must not work in a location where the faller is supported solely by a lifeline and harness.
Qualified assistance must be readily available to fallers in case of difficulty, emergency or injury.
Fallers and buckers must have an effective means to summon assistance.
Only a worker with duties associated with the falling activity may enter an active falling area.
Before entering the active falling area, workers must notify the faller or bucker and wait until advised by the faller or bucker that it is safe to enter.
A worker, in addition to the faller, may be at the base of a tree being felled if the worker is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: supervising or directing the falling activity,
training as a faller, or
required to assist the faller to overcome a specific falling difficulty.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 26.29.2 to 26.29.5 apply only to mechanical falling activities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limits on use of mechanical harvester
bcl:section.bcl:text: A mechanical harvester must not be used to fell a tree if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tree is in a condition that, if felled in that condition, it would pose a reasonably foreseeable risk to the harvester operator, or
the mechanical harvester is not capable of falling the tree safely.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a partially cut tree cannot be completely felled by a mechanical harvester and must be bypassed or left unattended, the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tree must be clearly marked;
work, other than that necessary to complete the falling of the tree, must stop in the hazard area until the tree is felled;
any worker who could enter the hazard area must be alerted to the hazard;
the person responsible for the direction and control of the mechanical harvesting activity must be notified.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person referred to in subsection (1) (d) must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all workers at risk are notified, and
the tree is safely felled before other work is undertaken in the hazard area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if incomplete falling is part of a planned process in which safe work practices acceptable to the Board are implemented.
Only a worker with duties associated with a mechanical falling activity may enter the active falling area.

Before a tree is felled by a mechanical harvester, all workers and equipment, other than the equipment operator and the harvesting equipment, must be clear of the area within a 2 tree-length radius of the tree.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Mechanical falling activities must be conducted in a manner that does not create any additional hazard for workers conducting subsequent work activities.
If, in any type of falling activity, a tree being felled may create a hazard to a user of a road, effective traffic control must be used to stop or control approaching traffic.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2003, App. C, s. 9.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 24.]
Sections 26.34 to 26.55 apply only to forestry operations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Only a designated worker may signal for the movement of cable yarding equipment, but any worker may signal to stop cable yarding equipment, and that signal must be obeyed promptly.
The worker designated to signal the yarder operator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not be otherwise occupied while the equipment is in motion, and
not signal for the movement of the equipment until assured that no workers are endangered within the area for which the designated worker is responsible.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The signals for rigging movement must be clearly discernible to the equipment operator, and to all workers who could be endangered by the movement of the equipment.
A worker who directs or operates equipment, or who could be endangered by the movement of equipment, must be familiar with the meaning of the signals.
The equipment operator must stop the equipment if a signal is not clearly understood.

If voice signals are being used that cannot be heard by workers who could be endangered by the movement of equipment, the equipment operator must not move the equipment until the operator has given a signal by means understandable to all those workers.
If voice signals are being used to direct the operation of a grapple yarder, the signals specified in Table 26-8 must be used.
If non-verbal signals such as whistles and hand signals are used to direct the operation of equipment, the signals specified in Tables 26-1 to 26-7 must be used.

When audible signals are being used concurrently to direct the operation of more than one piece of equipment, the signal tones must be differentiated to clearly identify intended movement of each machine.
Signalling devices must be tested at the start of each shift in a way that ensures that equipment will not be moved in response to the test.
Defective signalling devices that might cause a hazard to workers must not be used, and repairs, alterations, or adjustments to signalling devices must be performed by qualified persons.
A radio signalling device used to direct the movement of logging equipment must be designed, maintained and operated in accordance with a standard acceptable to the Board.
Any signalling system using radio frequency transmission must operate on a frequency and at a transmission power assigned and coordinated by a person acceptable to the Board.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 26.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a worker must not be transported on any cable system unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the system is authorized for use in a rescue, an emergency, an inspection or maintenance and it is being used for that purpose,
all other means for transportation are impracticable, and
the system is capable of withstanding the loads and stresses to be placed on it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the system is designed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by a professional engineer, and
for the purpose of the transport of workers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not be positioned within the bight of any running line under tension, nor in a position where the worker could be struck by a line if it were to break or come loose, or be tightened if slack.
A worker must be positioned in the clear to avoid being exposed to moving logs, saplings, root wads, chunks, rigging or other material.
A worker must be positioned clear of rigging which is stopped by an obstruction until the rigging has been slackened to reduce the hazard.
Despite subsection (1), a worker may enter the bight of a slack line to deal with an obstruction or set chokers.
If a worker enters the bight of a running line pursuant to subsection (4), the rigging must not be tightened until a clear go-ahead signal has been given by the worker.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Removal of potential hazards to rigging

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tree must be felled if the tree could

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: interfere with rig-up or with movement of lines and yarding equipment, or
be pushed or pulled into an area where a worker is working.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Saplings over 6Â m (20Â ft.) tall that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are located in an area to be yarded, and
constitute a reasonably foreseeable risk to workers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be felled before yarding activity begins.

If it is not practicable to comply with subsection (2), safe work practices acceptable to the Board that eliminate or minimize the risk to workers in the forestry operation may be used if these safe work practices are directed by a supervisor.
A standing tree may be used for anchoring lines or fastening blocks only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a suitable stump is not available, and
the tree is effectively tied back to another anchor, except that a secondary anchor tree need not be tied back.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A standing tree must not be used to anchor guylines if a worker would be endangered were the tree to be pulled over.

A stump or tree must not be used as an anchor for a line or for fastening a block until it has been determined that it is suitable for use as an anchor, and it must be inspected daily to determine that it remains suitable for continued use.
An anchor to which a haulback block is attached must have a notch of sufficient depth to retain the strap or must provide equivalent security by other effective means.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 29 (b).]
If a log, pipe or other apparatus buried in the ground is used to anchor a guyline or skyline, the method and equipment used must be acceptable to the Board and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the guyline or skyline must not be directly attached to the anchor,

a suitable strap or line of equal size and strength to the guyline or skyline with eyes in each end must be used, with one wrap around the anchor, and both eyes attached to the guyline or skyline with a shackle, and
the eye connection of the anchor strap must be visible for inspection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any anchor system not otherwise referred to in this section must be used in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: its design specifications and manufacturer's recommendations, or
if those specifications or recommendations are not known, a method acceptable to the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 29 (c).]
If an anchor system has 2 or more legs, bridle blocks of adequate strength must be used to distribute the load equally.
Guylines for a mobile yarder must be positioned

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as specified by the manufacturer, or
in a manner acceptable to the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Guylines must be rigged to provide a 45 degree or larger angle between the guyline and a line drawn plumb through the guyline fairlead.
If it is not practicable to comply with subsection (1) or (2), or if suitable anchors are not available, additional steps must be taken to ensure the stability of the yarder.
Guylines must be attached to the supported structure by guyline shackles, or other fastenings providing equivalent security.
Safety devices with breaking strength at least equal to that of the guylines must be installed at the top of mobile spars to prevent guylines or their assemblies from falling.
Guylines over a travelled road must be rigged to clear all traffic, or if this is not practicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the guylines must be conspicuously marked, and
signs warning of limited clearance must be posted on the road.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A guyline must be secured to its anchor stump in the following manner:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notch of sufficient depth, or another means of equivalent security, must be used to retain the wrapping lines;
sleeve shackles, knob and bell, screwy hooks or line clamps compatible with the guyline size must be used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If spikes are used to secure a guyline to an anchor stump, there must be at least

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 8 spikes in the first wrap, 3 spikes in the second wrap and 8 spikes in the last wrap if the guyline is attached to the yarder, or
3 spikes in the last wrap if the guyline is attached to a back spar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If spikes are used to secure a guyline to an anchor stump, there must be a minimum of 2 1/2 wraps of the guyline around the anchor stump.
Rigging must be of a type and size for which the equipment is designed.
Lines, blocks, and yarding and loading equipment must be rigged in accordance with accepted industry standards.
Shackle pins on stationary lines must be secured with molly hogans or other acceptable means to prevent accidental dislodgment.
Molly hogans must not be used to connect skylines, loading rigging, or any stationary lines.
Screw pin shackles used on running lines must be tightened securely and routinely inspected.
Rigging must be inspected at regular and frequent intervals by a qualified worker.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Straps for supporting blocks must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made from wire rope or synthetic fibre material, and
be of sufficient size and condition to withstand the maximum anticipated loads.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When properly anchored to a winch, the minimum number of wraps of cable left on a winch drum must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for skylines, 1 1/2 layers, and
for other types of logging equipment, 3 complete wraps.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a skidding winch mounted on ground-based skidding equipment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A knot must not be used in any winch line or other rigging, except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to effect temporary repair in the event of line breakage, or
for tag lines on grapple log loaders or for hooks on strawline eyes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A skyline must be anchored to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a stump or to a suitable manufactured anchor,
the base of a standing tree if the tree is tied back to a secondary anchor, or
a suitable piece of mobile equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A skyline must be secured to an anchor by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a choker using a large sleeve-type knockout pin shackle or an approved safety pin-type shackle over the skyline with the pin through the eye,
a strap acceptable to the Board, with both eyes hung in a shackle and the knockout pin or safety pin through the eye of the skyline, or
a wire rope clip system meeting the requirements of Part 15.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If anchor stumps in standing timber are used for slackline or other skyline operations, the skyline must be prevented from striking trees in the area, or the trees must be felled.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a skyline extension is used

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the breaking strength of the extension must be greater than or equal to that of the skyline,
the extension must not alter the safe capacity of the tower, and
if the carriage runs over it, the extension must be attached by a regular long splice or by a flush pin straight side shackle connecting the 2 eyes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each skyline spar must be of adequate strength.
An intermediate spar must be used in a manner acceptable to the Board.
Backspars must be topped unless workers are prohibited from entering the hazard area created when the skyline is loaded.
When rigged in a backspar, a skyline must be anchored no more than 8Â° off-line from the rearward projection of the skyline.
If a suitable anchor cannot be found to comply with subsection (1), another suitable anchor may be used provided that the backspar is stabilized by extra guylines.
The rearward projection of the skyline must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not be considered a guyline, and
not make an angle greater than 50Â° measured from the horizontal as it leaves the backspar unless approved by a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The method used to support a skyline at a backspar or intermediate spar must provide adequate support and protection for the line.
A skyline must not be fastened directly to a backspar.
A tree used as a backspar must be guyed with a sufficient number of guylines to ensure that the tree is adequately supported.
If spikes are used to anchor a backspar guyline

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the guyline must have at least 2 1/2 wraps around the stump, and
three spikes must be placed in sound wood on the last wrap.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 34.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: A lift tree must be topped or guyed unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tree is of adequate strength to withstand the loads that are placed on it during yarding activities,
the lines run through tail-hold blocks located so as to minimize stress on the tree, and
tail-holds are rigged and located to prevent a worker from being endangered if the tree is pulled over.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 35.]
Ground based skidding operations must be conducted using safe work practices acceptable to the Board, including, without limitation, the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not winching at an angle that could cause an obstruction to upset the equipment;
to avoid obstruction hang-up and rollover, if practicable, winching the turn up tight to the equipment before the equipment is moved;
selecting a suitable gear to maintain control of the equipment before climbing or descending grades;
dropping the turn to free the log if an unchoked log is picked up with a turn;
avoiding abrupt turns of equipment on side hills.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 35.]
If a sweep arm attached to a ROPS on a skidder is bent or deformed, prior to the use of the skidder

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a qualified person must determine whether the ROPS may be structurally damaged as a consequence of the damage to the sweep arm, and
if the ROPS may be structurally damaged, the ROPS must either be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: recertified by the manufacturer or a professional engineer as meeting the requirements of section 16.36, or
replaced.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A skidding winch on a ground based skidding machine must have a quick-release system to permit the winch line to run out freely and automatically disengage from its drum.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, work area includes any area in which any forestry work is done but does not include the travelled portion of a road unless that portion of the road is being used as a landing.
Work in a work area in a forestry operation must be planned and the work area must be located, constructed, maintained and operated to ensure the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: logs can be moved safely in the area;
log piles and equipment used to handle the logs do not become unstable or otherwise create a hazard;
workers are able to work in locations clear of moving logs and equipment;
workers are not exposed to incoming or runaway logs or other debris;
the area is kept free from buildup of bark and other debris to the extent that it would pose a risk to workers;
an effective method of dust control is used and maintained.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Log piles must, to the extent practicable, be located on stable and relatively level ground.
Log piles must not be higher than the safe operating reach of equipment being used to handle the logs.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 36.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log must not be passed over any worker or occupied vehicle or equipment.
Despite subsection (1), a log may be passed over a vehicle or equipment that is being loaded, if the log

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not pass over any portion of the vehicle or equipment that is occupied by a person, and
does not constitute a hazard for the occupant of the vehicle or equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not stand or pass under a suspended log.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 36.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Effective means of communication must be used in a forestry operation to control vehicle movements in any location where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a loader operator is unable to see the loading operation, or
log transporters are moving at landings, load-out points, water dumps, dry land sorts or railway reloads.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, for the purposes of subsection (1), audible signals are used as the means of communication, the signals must meet the requirements of section 26.34 and Table 26.2.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 36.]
Only persons permitted by law or by the workplace safe work procedures may be at landings, load-out points, water dumps, dry land sorts and railway reloads.

Bunk and stake assemblies, installed at a dry land sort for bundling logs, must have fixed stakes or be used with safe work procedures which ensure that no worker goes into the hazard area adjacent to or below self-tripping stakes unless the stakes are secured from releasing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cab guard means a barrier guarding the back of the cab of a log transporter;
certified welding inspector means a person who is certified as a Level 2 or Level 3 welding inspector in accordance with CSA Standard W178.2-08 (R2013), Certification of Welding Inspectors;

rated capacity, in relation to a cab guard, means the maximum cargo weight that may be transported by the log transporter and shift and contact the cab guard such that the cab guard is capable of withstanding a horizontal forward static load equal to 40% of that cargo weight, with this load uniformly distributed over the entire cab guard.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the protection of the driver of a log transporter, the log transporter must have a cab guard that meets all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (3), the cab guard is at least 15 cm (6 in) higher than the cab;
the cab guard is at least as wide as the cab;
the cab guard has no opening large enough to permit any item of cargo to pass through it;
the cab guard is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: constructed with a main supporting structure made of steel, or

certified by a professional engineer as having a main supporting structure designed and constructed so that vibration and distortion generated by use of the log transporter cannot damage the cab guard;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cab guard is installed in a manner that ensures that the rated capacity of the cab guard is not diminished.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The cab guard of a self-loading log transporter may be less than the height specified in subsection (2) (a) but must not be less than the cab height.
The weight of cargo that is being transported by a log transporter and that may shift and contact the cab guard must not exceed the rated capacity of the cab guard.
The operator of a log transporter must record the results of the inspection, made before the start of operation on the shift, of the cab guard of the log transporter.
A log transporter must be removed from service if there are any cracks, damage or other conditions that will decrease the rated capacity of the cab guard of the log transporter.
A log transporter removed from service under subsection (6) must not be returned to service until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cab guard is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: repaired, and
inspected and certified to meet the rated capacity by the manufacturer, a professional engineer or a certified welding inspector, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cab guard is replaced by a cab guard that meets the requirements of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The cab guard of a log transporter must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permanently marked with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the name and address of its manufacturer,
the model number or serial number of the cab guard, and
the rated capacity of the cab guard, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identified by carrying in the log transporter a copy of a letter that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: accurately describes the cab guard,
certifies the model number or serial number of the cab guard and the rated capacity of the cab guard, and
has been signed by the manufacturer or a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log transporter carrying a log load must be equipped with bunks and stakes of adequate design and construction to safely perform their intended function.
Bunks must be able to rotate freely upon their pivots, if designed to do so.
Stakes, extensions and stake cables must be installed and maintained to ensure that when the log transporter is loaded

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the angle between the bunks and stakes at the base does not exceed 90, and
the angle between the bunks and the stakes and extensions above the base does not exceed the angle at which the stakes and extensions can safely withstand the maximum anticipated loads.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Stakes must be constructed so that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: they can be released only from the opposite end of the bunk,
keeper pins are secured against unintended release, and
if they are over 1.2Â m (4Â ft) in height, springs or other mechanical means are fitted to facilitate their returning to a vertical position.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not go on bunks and trailer assemblies to raise or lower stakes and extensions unless it is impracticable to do otherwise.
If a worker must go on a bunk or trailer assembly to collapse stakes or extensions, the worker must be provided a safe means of getting on and off the bunk or trailer assembly.
Procedures must be developed and implemented for collapsing stakes or extensions during adverse weather conditions.
Stake extensions must be secured against inadvertent detachment from the stakes.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 39 (c).]
Stake cables must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not be made from swaged wire rope, and
conform to the following specifications.

oasis:entry.oasis:line: â‰¥ 2.6 m (8 ft 6 in) and â‰¤ 2.9 m (9 ft 6 in)
> 2.9 m (9 ft 6 in) and â‰¤ 3.7 m (12 ft)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Stake and bunk assemblies must be inspected daily, and must not be used if they show signs of excessive wear.
A record of all inspections conducted under subsection (8) must be maintained.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 20/2008, App. A, s. 39 (e).]
If logs are being loaded on a log transporter,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there must be an effective means of communication between the transporter operator and any workers involved in the loading, and
each worker involved in or in the vicinity of the loading must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: be in a safe location, and
without limiting subparagraph (i),

bcl:clause.bcl:text: be clear of any moving logs or logs that might move or fall,
not be standing on the cab of a truck or between the cab of the truck and a log being loaded, and
not be resting any part of the worker's body on a log.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log load on a log transporter must meet the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the log load and the log transporter

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are stable, without the use of wrappers or tiedowns, during loading and prior to transportation, and
will remain stable, after the log load is secured in accordance with section 26.68, during transportation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the log load does not impair the free and full movement of the log transporter;
the working load limits of stakes and stake cables are not exceeded;
to ensure that stakes remain at a safe angle, the bottom layer of logs is laid tight and arranged to minimize slack in the stake cables;
the bottom layer and side rows of the log load extend horizontally beyond at least 2 sets of stakes

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least 30 cm (11.8 in) on compensating-reach-type trailers, or
at least 15 cm (5.9 in) on other types of log transporters;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a log whose length is shorter than the distance between the stakes is not loaded above the top of the stakes unless the log is in a secure position;
the horizontal centreline of the top log in a side row that is immediately adjacent to a stake is not higher than the top of the stake;
if wrappers or tiedowns are used to secure a log stack of 3 or more layers, the top of the log stack is curved so that the middle part of the curve is higher than the sides of the curve;
the length of each log does not exceed the design limitations of a highway or other surface that the log transporter travels on;
the log load does not include limbs that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pose a risk of injury to a person, or
impair the safe operation of the log transporter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a log load must be secured in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this section, and
whichever of the following sections applies:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 26.68.1 [highways and mixed transportation routes];
section 26.68.2 [entirely off-highway transportation routes].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log transporter carrying a log load that is not yet secured as required by subsection (1) may be moved within a loading area if no person is exposed to the risk of logs, log chunks or debris falling off the log transporter.
If a log load is secured on a log transporter using wrappers or tiedowns, the following requirements must be met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the wrappers and tiedowns must be installed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the loading area or at a location that is close to the loading area,
as soon as practicable after the log load is loaded on the log transporter and, if the log transporter is a trailer, before the trailer is connected to a truck, and
so that

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the log load is secure and no logs, log chunks or debris will fall off the log transporter while the log load is being transported,
the wrappers and tiedowns can be safely removed while load restraining equipment is in position,
no working load limit of a wrapper or tiedown is exceeded and each anchor point for a tiedown has at least the working load limit of the tiedown, and
each tiedown is located within 60 cm (23.6 in) horizontally from a bunk, flatdeck or other load supporting surface;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during transportation, the wrappers and tiedowns must be checked and kept tight;
logs in the log load must not be shifted or moved while the wrappers and tiedowns are installed or adjusted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tiedown must not be used to secure a log load on a log transporter unless the tiedown is marked with its working load limit.
Subject to subsection (6), bundle straps and banding must not be used to secure a log load on a log transporter.
Bundle straps and banding may be used to secure a log load on a log transporter in a loading area if no person is exposed to the risk of logs, log chunks or debris falling off the log transporter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Securing log loads â€” highways and mixed transportation routes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to the transportation of a log load if all or part of the transportation route, other than a crossing, is a highway.

A log load must be secured in accordance with the federal cargo securement standard and, for the purposes of this section, a reference in the standard to a highway is to be read as a reference to any road.
Section 2.3 [conflict with code or standard] does not apply in relation to the federal cargo securement standard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Securing log loads â€” entirely off-highway transportation routes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to the transportation of a log load if no part of the transportation route, other than a crossing, is a highway.
A log load must be secured on a log transporter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by installing, on each log stack and on any logs that are not part of a log stack, the following number of wrappers or tiedowns that conform to subsectionÂ (3):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the longest log that is to be secured by the wrappers or tiedowns is no more than 10.7Â m (35Â ft) long, at least 2 wrappers or tiedowns, each of which has a working load limit of at least 8.9Â kN (2Â 000Â lbf);

if the longest log that is to be secured by the wrappers or tiedowns is more than 10.7Â m (35Â ft) long, at least 3 wrappers or tiedowns, each of which has a working load limit of at least 13.3Â kN (3Â 000Â lbf), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without the use of wrappers or tiedowns by loading the logs

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: lengthwise with the horizontal centrelines of all of the logs below the top of the stakes on the log transporter, and
in accordance with the requirements set out in a current risk assessment that conforms to subsection (4) for the log hauling operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A wrapper or tiedown installed for the purposes of subsection (2) (a) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a safety factor of at least the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if wire rope, 4;
if polyester rope, 7;
if any other synthetic rope, 12;
if synthetic webbing, 3;
if chain, 4, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if chain, have a grade of at least 70.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (b), a risk assessment for a log hauling operation must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in writing,
be prepared by a qualified person, based on the circumstances of the log hauling operation, including, without limitation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the speeds of the log transporters used in the operation,
the type, design and condition of the surfaces that the log transporters will travel on, including their grades,
the weather, and
the log characteristics,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify requirements for the loading, transportation and unloading of logs, and

set out the opinion of the qualified person that no logs, log chunks or debris will fall off a log transporter during loading, transportation or unloading of logs if the specified requirements are met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A log load that is secured under subsection (2) (b) in reliance on a current risk assessment must be transported and unloaded in accordance with the requirements set out in that assessment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Removing wrappers and tiedowns and releasing stakes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, removal station means a structure that is designed to protect a person from being struck by logs, log chunks or debris falling off a log transporter when

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a wrapper or tiedown installed on a log load is removed, or
a stake securing logs on a log transporter is released.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following activities must be conducted in accordance with written safe work procedures prepared by a qualified person:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: removing a wrapper or tiedown installed on a log load;
releasing a stake securing logs on a log transporter;
using a removal station.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The written safe work procedures referred to in subsection (2) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: posted in a conspicuous location at any place where the activities referred to in that subsection take place and maintained in a legible condition, or
effectively communicated to the workers and supervisors who conduct those activities if it is not practicable to post the safe work procedures in a conspicuous location.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Wrappers and tiedowns must not be removed and stakes securing logs on a log transporter must not be released when a person is preparing to unload logs from a log transporter unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is using a removal station, or
the logs are otherwise restrained to prevent them from falling on the person who is removing the wrappers or tiedowns or releasing the stakes.
